chapter.htmlHeader: What is the prognosis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
The reported prognosis of sepsis and septic shock varies in the literature, depending on the definitions used and the population studied [Singer, 2016].

  • Organ dysfunction is an important predictor of prognosis, with multiple organ involvement being associated with a higher risk of mortality [Cecconi, 2018]. Extremes of age and the presence of co-morbidities are also associated with a worse prognosis [Daniels, 2017].
    • A UK Sepsis Trust report cites an overall mortality rate in England of 28.9% [Daniels, 2017].
    • A UK observational cohort study of 91 intensive care units (n = 56,673) found that the hospital mortality rate of adults admitted with sepsis ranged from 17% in people aged 16–19 years, to 64% in people aged over 85 years [Padkin, 2003].
    • A US study of two hospital cohorts estimated that sepsis contributed to one-third to one-half of all in-hospital deaths [Liu, 2014].
    • A diagnosis of septic shock is associated with hospital mortality rates greater than 40% [Singer, 2016]. An international study of the association between following Surviving Sepsis Campaign (SSC) performance criteria and mortality rate (n = 29,470) found the overall hospital mortality for people with sepsis and septic shock was 32.8% [Levy, 2014].
  • The case fatality rate of sepsis may be falling over time, presumably due to increased awareness and reporting of suspected sepsis, faster diagnosis, and improved management protocols [Ruth, 2014; Gotts, 2016].
    • A US retrospective observational cohort study of acute paediatric hospitalizations in seven US states found the case fatality rate fell from 10.3% to 8.9% from 1995 to 2005 [Hartman, 2013].
    • An observational study (2001–10) found 5.1% of deaths in England were associated with sepsis, according to cause of death data extracted from the Office for National Statistics mortality database. The sepsis-associated death rate increased over the study period, peaking in 2006, and then decreased [McPherson, 2013].
  • Survivors of sepsis have higher rates of mortality following hospital discharge compared with control populations.
    • A US systematic review of long-term mortality and quality-of-life data from 30 low- to moderate-quality studies found people with sepsis have higher mortality rates after hospital discharge than the general population, with one-year mortality rates ranging from 7–43% [Winters, 2010].
    • A US observational longitudinal, prospective cohort study (1998–2010, n = 960) found that a diagnosis of sepsis was directly associated with an absolute increase in 'late mortality' (defined as death from 31 days to 2 years after hospital admission) of [Prescott, 2016]:
      • 22.1% compared with age- and sex-matched adults not in hospital.
      • 10.4% compared with age- and sex-matched adults admitted with non-sepsis infection.
      • It concluded that more than one in five people who survive sepsis have a late death not explained by health status prior to the sepsis episode, and sepsis is an additional risk factor for late mortality.
  • Compared to non-sepsis admissions, sepsis survivors have a greater risk of re-admission, with 30-day re-admission rates averaging between 19–32% [Daniels, 2017]. People who survive sepsis may have long-term physical, psychological, and cognitive impairments [Singer, 2016].
